page.title: 02NATURAL FEATURES AND HISTORY
page.content: The area covered is attractive scenically.The southern end of the block is mainly flat and intensively farmed but rises to a height of 411' along the Felixkirk to Kirby Knowle ridge,falling again towards South Kilvington village. The land is productive but heavy, overlaying boulder clay;mixed farming, arable and permanent grass. There is good tree cover, chiefly deciduous, with mature hedgerow trees and several larger wooded areas. Except in the flatter land around Marderby Hall, hedges generally are very good and not cut very low; therefore they provide good cover and nesting sites for song birds, smaller passerines, and small mammals. Foxes and badgers have been recorded and hares exist in fair numbers.
